results.title: Lumiere programme [Silent version]
results.brief_description: The first public film show in Great Britain was given at the Regent Street Polytechnic London, on February 20th, 1896, by the brothers August and Louis Lumiere. This film is a complete reprint of the programs shown on that occasion. It comprises the following subjects: Workers leaving the Lumiere factory; Baby at the lunch table; Demolition of a wall; Watering the gardener; Congress of Photographic Societies at Neuville-Sur-Saone, July 1895; Arrival of a train at Ciotat Station; A game of cards; A boat leaving harbour. None of these films is more than a single shot, without cutting or camera movement; their interest lay entirely in the novelty of the moving photograph.

This version includes a piano accompaniment and narration which was added in 1956.

results.title: Lumiere D'ete = Summer Light
results.brief_description:
An ex-dancer runs an isolated mountain hotel where the guests are ‘people with problems’. This melancholy allegory about characters living on the edge of a figurative and literal abyss, was made under the restrictions of Vichy France and at times threatened by censorship. Visually, [during the Occupation] the new films became more mannered and stylized, surpassing even the expressionistic vistas of ‘realisme poetique’ in their creation of visual fields removed both from every day reality and from the characters who moved within them. Some works returned to overt pictorialism of late silent film, perhaps most notably Gremillon and Prevert’s ‘Lumiere d’Ete’. Sets were often large and elaborate, despite obvious financial difficulties that this entailed in a period of limited resources. Roger Regent, one of the period’s most astute observers, spoke of the ‘decor-personnage’ (the set as character) as being an often abused cinematic cliche. If decor could frequently function as a kind of (impersonal) character, fictional beings could by the same token lapse into relative, sometimes absolute stillness, assuming the function of decor in a larger, metaphysical drama.” Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of Image: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992

Credits: Producer, Andre Paulve ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writers, Jacques Prevert, Pierre Laroche ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Roland Manuel ; art direction, Max Douy, Louis Barsacq.
Cast: Paul Bernard, Madeleine Renaud, Pierre Brasseur, Madeleine Robinson, Raymond Aimos, Georges Marchal, Jane Marken, Charles Blavette.

results.title: Lumiere and company
results.creator_credit: Cineteve, Igeldo Komunikazioa, La Sept-Arte, Studio Canal+, Soren Staermose AB, Neal Edelstein and Fabienne Servan-Schreiber
results.brief_description:
These are the rules: No post editing; no synchronous sound; no more than three takes. The facts: only 52 seconds of film using an original restored 35mm Lumiere camera. 40 filmmakers from around the world partake in one of the most fascinating and enlightening cinematic experiments in film history, to commemorate the centennial of the Lumiere Brothers’ first motion picture. “From slapstick comedy to political propaganda, documentary realism to costume drama, the world is fleetingly captured once again. But the lens of the contemporary beholders has seen a century the Lumiere brothers could scarcely have imagined. Watching the directors it is hard to decide which side of the camera provides the greater entertainment! Who cranks the handle themselves or who insists on a full technical crew; who conquers, or cracks under the constraints is fascinating and just as illuminating as the succinct sensations they create.” - Amree Hewitt. 45th Melbourne International Film Festival, 1996.
Directed by:
Theodoros Angelopoulos (as Theo Angelopoulos)
Vicente Aranda
John Boorman
Youssef Chahine
Alain Corneau
Costa-Gavras
Raymond Depardon
Francis Girod
Peter Greenaway
Lasse Hallström
Hugh Hudson
Gaston Kaboré
Abbas Kiarostami
Cédric Klapisch
Andrey Konchalovskiy (as Andrei Konchalovsky)
Spike Lee
Claude Lelouch
Bigas Luna
Sarah Moon
Arthur Penn
Lucian Pintilie
Helma Sanders-Brahms (as Helma Sanders)
Jerry Schatzberg
Nadine Trintignant
Fernando Trueba
Liv Ullmann
Jaco Van Dormael
Régis Wargnier
Wim Wenders
Yoshishige Yoshida (as Kiju Yoshida)
Yimou Zhang
Merzak Allouache (segment “Merzak Allouache/Aubervilliers”)

Michael Haneke (segment “Michael Haneke/Vienne”)
James Ivory (segment “Merchant Ivory/Paris”)
Patrice Leconte (segment “La Ciotat 1996/Patrice Leconte”)
David Lynch (segment “Premonition Following An Evil Deed”)
Ismail Merchant (segment “Merchant Ivory/Paris”)
Claude Miller (segment “Claude Miller/Paris”)
Idrissa Ouedraogo (segment “Idrissa Ouedraogo/Burkina Faso”)
Jacques Rivette (segment “Jacques Rivette/Paris”)

results.title: Lumiere
results.brief_description:
Compilation film based on reels shot by the brothers Lumiere and their staff. It contains street scenes and public events: cruise on the Seine, the lift of the Eiffel Tower, a visit of Czar Nicholas II to Paris in 1896. Those scenes are the earliest sights of Paris ever recorded on film

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, Marc Allegret ; music, Henri Sauguet.

results.title: Lumaaq: an Eskimo legend [French version] = Lumaaq: une legende esquimo
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Pierre Moretti and Co Hoedeman
results.brief_description: Lumaaq tells the story of a legend widely believed by the Povungnituk Innuit. The artist’s drawings are transferred to paper, cut out and animated under the camera. The result is Innuit prints in action. Dialogue, music and artwork make this film a total cultural transplant. Sound film without commentary.

results.title: Lulu on the bridge
results.creator_credit: Redeemable Features, Peter Newman, Greg Johnson, Amy Kaufman and Paul Auster
results.brief_description: Writer Paul Auster made his solo directorial debut with this romantic drama that combines myth and realism in a form of storytelling that is both simple and complex. Izzy Maurer is a jazz saxophonist whose life is permanently changed when he is hit by a stray bullet. After his recovery, Izzy can no longer play and falls into a depression. He stumbles across the body of a stranger and ends up with the dead man’s briefcase. Inside, he discovers a mysterious stone which leads him to Celia Burns, an aspiring actress and listener of his music. Together, they discover the power of the stone and the threat of those who want it, as the story takes a dark and surprising turn into the Pandora’s Box of Izzy’s soul. Cast includes Harvey Keitel, Mira Sorvino, Willem Dafoe, Gina Gershon and Vanessa Redgrave.

results.title: Luke's Party
results.brief_description: A young woman sits herself in front of a video camera to document her struggles as a single mother. By the time she has finished dealing with her bills, her children’s demands, her best friend’s questions and trying to arrange her son’s birthday, we understand only too well how difficult life can be. A very funny and very affectionate look at working class urban life.

results.title: Luke's party
results.creator_credit: AFI [au], Tim Burns and Ros Sultan
results.brief_description: A woman picks up a video camera to make a mock documentary about growing up Aborigine in South Australia. As the camera starts rolling she is continually interrupted by the demands of children, friends, telephone repair people, neighbours, salespeople and representatives of a range of government bureacracies. This delightfully tongue-in-cheek short film makes salient points about the difficulties of maintaining personal dignity in a world of economic and emotional uncertainty. The futililty of her attempt to explain “herself” on camera as the world around her descends into absurd farce satirises the pretend objectivity of most social-realist documentary. Sharp, witty and suprisingly passionate, “Luke’s Party” is an exceptional short Australian film.
